questions.text: A 26-year-old male resident is noticed by his attending physician to have yellow eyes after his 24-hour call period. When asked, the resident states he has no medical history, but on occasion, he has thought he might have mild jaundice when he is stressed or has more than four to five alcoholic drinks. He never sought medical treatment because he was uncertain, and his eyes would return fully to normal within 2 days. He denies nausea, abdominal pain, dark urine, light-colored stools, pruritus, or weight loss. On examination, he has a BMI of 20.1 kg/m2. Scleral icterus is present. There are no stigmata of chronic liver disease. Laboratory examinations are normal except for a total bilirubin of 3.0 mg/dL. Direct bilirubin is 0.2 mg/dL. AST, ALT, alkaline phosphatase and haptoglobin are normal. Which of the following is the mostlikely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old man was admitted due to asymptomatic persistent jaundice. His siblings had jaundice with direct hyperbilirubinemia. Physical examination revealed icteric sclera without hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory findings showed increased serum bilirubin (4.8 mg/dl) with direct bilirubin 3.4 mg/dl. On bromsulphalein clearance test, No clearance occurred and reflux of conjugated was present. What is the expected liver biopsy feature in this patient?

questions.text: A 29-year old, 4-month pregnant primigravida has a h/o juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. She has been regularly taking sodium valproate and now seeking an opinion for her antiepileptic regimen. What would you suggest her-

questions.correct_answer: B. Continue valproate with monitoring of drug level

questions.text: A known alcoholic is brought to the emergency department by his wife. The person has not consumed alcohol for the past two days due to religious reasons. The person complained of nausea, vomiting and dizziness. On the second day, he developed seizures, that progressed to generalized tonic clonic seizures (GTCs). Which of the following would be the best medication to manage the seizures of the patient?

A person waiting for a train on a railway platform starts having seizures. He has a band showing him to be an epileptic on medication and his medications are in his pocket. What should be the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Take the person away from the train, make sure he does not fall, meanwhile call for medical help and transfer him to hospital

options.label: B
options.text: Take the person away from the train, stuff handkerchief in his mouth, hold his hands and feet till the seizure subsides, then transfer him to hospital

options.label: C
options.text: Take the person away from the train, make him lie down by holding his leg up, give him medications and then transfer him to hospital

options.label: D
options.text: Take the person away from the train, give him medications and water and then transfer him to hospital

questions.correct_answer: A. Take the person away from the train, make sure he does not fall, meanwhile call for medical help and transfer him to hospital

questions.text: A 16 year old girl is brought to the emergency department after losing consciousness for minutes.She was accompanied by her father who witnessed the event.The following clinical feature may help differentiate between seizure and a syncopal attack.

questions.correct_answer: A. Posterior temporal and parietal lobes,dominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with an acute stroke. On examination he has mild right arm and face weakness. He has spontaneous speech with occasional paraphasic errors. He can understand and follow commands. Repetition is severely impaired. Which of the following best explains his speech pattern?

A 62-year-old female presents for stroke evaluation due to acute right hemiparesis for the last several hours. On examination, she has a right facial droop with right arm weakness and mild sensory changes in the right arm. She is noted to have effortful and fragmented speech, and is unable to name several objects. Her comprehension is intact, but she has difficulty with repetition. Which of the following arteries is the most likely cause of her stroke?

options.text: Inferior division of middle cerebral artery.

options.label: D
options.text: Superior division of middle cerebral artery.

questions.correct_answer: D. Superior division of middle cerebral artery.

Antibody in Goodpasture syndrome :

options.label: A
options.text: Antibody against NC1 domain of alpha 5 chain of collagen 4

options.label: B
options.text: Antibody against NC1 domain of alpha 4 chain of collagen 4

options.label: C
options.text: Antibody against NC1 domain of alpha 3 chain of collagen 3

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: D. Antibody against NC1 domain of alpha 3 chain of collagen 4

options.label: B

options.label: C

Which of the following statements about ADPKD and intracranial aneurysm is true?

options.label: A
options.text: All ADPKD patients should be screened for intracranial aneurysms.

options.label: C
options.text: The risk for rupture of an intracranial aneurysm depends on its size and location.

options.label: D
options.text: Magnetic resonance angiography to screen for intracranial aneurysms is contraindicated in advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) because it requires administration of gadolinium.

questions.correct_answer: C. The risk for rupture of an intracranial aneurysm depends on its size and location.
